content: I don't believe DIs are allowed to strike recruits. Another great movie on this topic is The DI starring Jack Webb. Here's a mini review... Why is it Jack Webb gets no respect as a director? This film puts to death the myth that Webb was a one-trick ("Dragnet") pony. Marines then and now call "The D.I." the most accurate portrayal of boot camp training ever put on celluloid. It's also a marvelous character study, with gripping performances by both Webb and Don Dubbins. What makes it even more amazing is: 1) Only three of the men in this film were professional actors; Webb, Dubbins and Lin McCarthy, and Dubbins had been a Marine. All the others were actual Marines, and Webb elicted memorable performances from most of them. 2) It was shot in a breathtaking 23 days in March of 1957. 3) To make the summer release date requested by Warner Bros., Webb edited as he shot. By the time principal photography wrapped, he had two reels cut and scored. "http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0050283/"

content: Scooter, The night before I went to basic (1982), I saw 'The DI' on the late night movie. Not the best choice in terms of quelling the butterflies in my stomach. Jack Webb was one of the best. His intensity and desire to 'get the story right' was legion. His 'Dragnet' series was a radio program before it was a TV series, and it earned high marks from the San Francisco PD for its honest and forthright portrayal of police work. Prior to Dragnet, 'paperwork' and 'procedure' were almost unknown on detective shows and movies. Detectives and police ran around with guns drawn and shot it out with bad guys. Credit Jack Webb for changing that model and making police dramas more realistic and thought provoking. He brought that same method to his classic about the Marine Corps. Nearly every scene was taken from interviews of actual DIs that Jack brought in as advisors for the movie. Not that I appreciated it at the time I saw it. My thoughts at the time centered on "What the h3ll have I gotten myself in to?" Sullivan013

content: There is a great limit on what can be done to you during "boot", but you put up with it because you know it's for the better. On the other hand others put with it happening to you because it will be better for them. Not that they are afraid to speak out, but because the other has done something to them. DI's don't get on you because it's fun for them. They are trying to make a better person out of you. It would be easier for them to write you up and discharge you as unfit for military service. It does not stop with basic. First duty station we had a 1st class clusterflop of a person. He was late for everything, work, guard relief. When he was there 50% output was good on some days. I was cleaning and repairing the sections camo nets one day after an FTX, he was supossed to assist me. SSG V checked on us(me) three times before lunch, Pvt S----bird was never there. After lunch he still was a noshow. When SSG V finally found him them had a counseling session in the equipment room. He came to me crying and trying to show the elbow shaped welts on his chest, with out looking up I said 'I don't see a thing'. He kept harping how SSG V hit him, I again stated 'I don't see a thing, SSG V has been in his office for the last hour'. He wizened up for about a couple of weeks and was then booted for passing bad checks. I'll have to check out "The DI", going over to netflix.

content: FMJ is a great movie for entertainment purposes, and for giving RDC's/DI's a few cute phrases to utilize around the recruits... That's about it really. I don't know about now, or about other branches of the service. But I went to boot at Great Mistakes...err Lakes... There were two kinds of divisions, co-ed and all male. I was in an all male division, and had this crusty old GMC, he laid down the law, and what he said we did. He had kind of a fatherly manner in the way he talked, but he also had the ability to back up whatever he said. I have heard of recruits being hit, but never saw it. I have heard of blanket parties, never saw one... We did stuff one guy in a laundry sack for winning us an ice cream party though...and we won ourselves another one for that stunt. I'll be brutally honost, if you do your damned best, keep your mouth shut, boot camp ain't too bad. The best part of boot camp for me was leaving, when GMC asked me one question after graduation, "Who are you?". If you do well in boot camp you are largely unnoticed, if you screw up, the DI WILL know your name, and WILL know your face, which means YOU WILL be physically stronger by the time you leave. Like IT1 Scaffe told us, "I want it to rain in here" as we did about 45 mins of trying to push the Earth into a new orbital path. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: After the military... It's your life, live it how you want to then. After you are out the GI bill is good for college classes if you enlist after high school. Also I believe with the new bill it can be transferred to a spouse or child but not 100% sure, legal speak is not my strong suit. Jobs after the military, that's another story. Military people have so much going for them, if they just step back and take a look. In the military we are big on the team concept, and so many vets don't mention what THEY did, say maybe you ended up as the POIC of a small sentry boat at Norfolk one day. You might not ever give it another thought, which is a mistake, mention it on a resume, it shows many things, leadership experience, safe operation of machinery, navigation. What the military gives you(or more actually, offers you, you got to choose to take and use them) is the tools to do anything you want to. If you get out and want to be a police officer, cite your firearms training, deadly force training, anti-terrorism training, etc. You want to be a car mechanic? Mention the work you did on deisel engines as an A-ganger, or the hummers you did periodic maintenance on when you got stuck in the motor pool. That's the key my friend. The military isn't going to lay it out for you and tie a bow on it. You will give you something no school ever will, real world experience, under the most extreme conditions. Now look at it from the employers perspective, would you higher the 22 year old kid that has been in a classroom for the last 17 years, or the 22 year old that did time in the middle east, north america, and korea. Bassically, a college kid has the theory, the book smarts if you will. Me, I can't tell you what makes an engine make this sound or that, but I can strip it down, fix it, have no "extra" parts and it runs like new. Which one do you want to hire? “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: I don't know about now but in the US Army in 1961 a DS could physically kick your butt and they did. When I got to my TOE outfit it so happened that one of my DS's transferred in and became my Plat Daddy. He took one look at me did a double take and said "Squad leader? Fckin' amazin'". But we got along fine. Later, while sharing some brewski's, I asked him why he was so hard on me in basic. He told me, "Some guys you can talk to. Other individuals are like mules. You gotta hit 'em with a plank to get their attention. You were a mule". Then he took a long swig and added, "so was I". It was a draftee army. Some of the recruits were already hard as concrete and didn't want to be there so the DS's were afforded all the ammo they needed. Funny thing is, a lot of the guys who were dragged kicking and screaming into the Military found a home and turned into lifers. It wasn't the demoralized draftee Army we had in the '70's. More like WWII I think.

FMJ did rely on R Lee Ermy's expertise as a former USMC Drill Instructor...and the settings for the barracks interior (Parris Island) were prety damn close to the real thing... But...Jack Webb did the role better... Oh yes... Scottrj50... That's no M-1...at 'high port'... That's an M16A2 at 'right shoulder arms'... The platoon in the picture is undergoing 'Drill Competition'... Get your facts straight before you post out of your realm of expertise...

content: I don't believe DIs are allowed to strike recruits. Another great movie on this topic is The DI starring Jack Webb. Here's a mini review... Why is it Jack Webb gets no respect as a director? This film puts to death the myth that Webb was a one-trick ("Dragnet") pony. Marines then and now call "The D.I." the most accurate portrayal of boot camp training ever put on celluloid. It's also a marvelous character study, with gripping performances by both Webb and Don Dubbins. What makes it even more amazing is: 1) Only three of the men in this film were professional actors; Webb, Dubbins and Lin McCarthy, and Dubbins had been a Marine. All the others were actual Marines, and Webb elicted memorable performances from most of them. 2) It was shot in a breathtaking 23 days in March of 1957. 3) To make the summer release date requested by Warner Bros., Webb edited as he shot. By the time principal photography wrapped, he had two reels cut and scored. "http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0050283/"

content: Scooter, The night before I went to basic (1982), I saw 'The DI' on the late night movie. Not the best choice in terms of quelling the butterflies in my stomach. Jack Webb was one of the best. His intensity and desire to 'get the story right' was legion. His 'Dragnet' series was a radio program before it was a TV series, and it earned high marks from the San Francisco PD for its honest and forthright portrayal of police work. Prior to Dragnet, 'paperwork' and 'procedure' were almost unknown on detective shows and movies. Detectives and police ran around with guns drawn and shot it out with bad guys. Credit Jack Webb for changing that model and making police dramas more realistic and thought provoking. He brought that same method to his classic about the Marine Corps. Nearly every scene was taken from interviews of actual DIs that Jack brought in as advisors for the movie. Not that I appreciated it at the time I saw it. My thoughts at the time centered on "What the h3ll have I gotten myself in to?" Sullivan013

content: There is a great limit on what can be done to you during "boot", but you put up with it because you know it's for the better. On the other hand others put with it happening to you because it will be better for them. Not that they are afraid to speak out, but because the other has done something to them. I was cleaning and repairing the sections camo nets one day after an FTX, he was supossed to assist me. SSG V checked on us(me) three times before lunch, Pvt S----bird was never there. After lunch he still was a noshow. When SSG V finally found him them had a counseling session in the equipment room. He came to me crying and trying to show the elbow shaped welts on his chest, with out looking up I said 'I don't see a thing'. He kept harping how SSG V hit him, I again stated 'I don't see a thing, SSG V has been in his office for the last hour'. He wizened up for about a couple of weeks and was then booted for passing bad checks. I'll have to check out "The DI", going over to netflix.

content: FMJ is a great movie for entertainment purposes, and for giving RDC's/DI's a few cute phrases to utilize around the recruits... That's about it really. I don't know about now, or about other branches of the service. But I went to boot at Great Mistakes...err Lakes... There were two kinds of divisions, co-ed and all male. I was in an all male division, and had this crusty old GMC, he laid down the law, and what he said we did. He had kind of a fatherly manner in the way he talked, but he also had the ability to back up whatever he said. I have heard of recruits being hit, but never saw it. I have heard of blanket parties, never saw one... We did stuff one guy in a laundry sack for winning us an ice cream party though...and we won ourselves another one for that stunt. I'll be brutally honost, if you do your damned best, keep your mouth shut, boot camp ain't too bad. The best part of boot camp for me was leaving, when GMC asked me one question after graduation, "Who are you?". If you do well in boot camp you are largely unnoticed, if you screw up, the DI WILL know your name, and WILL know your face, which means YOU WILL be physically stronger by the time you leave. Like IT1 Scaffe told us, "I want it to rain in here" as we did about 45 mins of trying to push the Earth into a new orbital path. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: After the military... It's your life, live it how you want to then. After you are out the GI bill is good for college classes if you enlist after high school. Also I believe with the new bill it can be transferred to a spouse or child but not 100% sure, legal speak is not my strong suit. Jobs after the military, that's another story. Military people have so much going for them, if they just step back and take a look. In the military we are big on the team concept, and so many vets don't mention what THEY did, say maybe you ended up as the POIC of a small sentry boat at Norfolk one day. You might not ever give it another thought, which is a mistake, mention it on a resume, it shows many things, leadership experience, safe operation of machinery, navigation. What the military gives you(or more actually, offers you, you got to choose to take and use them) is the tools to do anything you want to. If you get out and want to be a police officer, cite your firearms training, deadly force training, anti-terrorism training, etc. You want to be a car mechanic? Mention the work you did on deisel engines as an A-ganger, or the hummers you did periodic maintenance on when you got stuck in the motor pool. That's the key my friend. The military isn't going to lay it out for you and tie a bow on it. You will give you something no school ever will, real world experience, under the most extreme conditions. Now look at it from the employers perspective, would you higher the 22 year old kid that has been in a classroom for the last 17 years, or the 22 year old that did time in the middle east, north america, and korea. Bassically, a college kid has the theory, the book smarts if you will. Me, I can't tell you what makes an engine make this sound or that, but I can strip it down, fix it, have no "extra" parts and it runs like new. Which one do you want to hire? “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: I don't know about now but in the US Army in 1961 a DS could physically kick your butt and they did. When I got to my TOE outfit it so happened that one of my DS's transferred in and became my Plat Daddy. He took one look at me did a double take and said "Squad leader? Fckin' amazin'". But we got along fine. Later, while sharing some brewski's, I asked him why he was so hard on me in basic. He told me, "Some guys you can talk to. Other individuals are like mules. You gotta hit 'em with a plank to get their attention. You were a mule". Then he took a long swig and added, "so was I". It was a draftee army. Some of the recruits were already hard as concrete and didn't want to be there so the DS's were afforded all the ammo they needed. Funny thing is, a lot of the guys who were dragged kicking and screaming into the Military found a home and turned into lifers. It wasn't the demoralized draftee Army we had in the '70's. More like WWII I think.
